entities.name: SCIENCE BEHIND SLEEP
entities.description: The exploration of the biological and physiological processes involved in sleep, including stages, regulation, and importance for health and well-being

entities.name: RAPID EYE MOVEMENT (REM) SLEEP
entities.description: A stage of sleep characterized by rapid eye movements, increased brain activity, and muscle paralysis, associated with dreaming and memory consolidation

entities.name: NON-REM SLEEP
entities.description: A stage of sleep divided into three stages (N1, N2, N3) that progresses from light to deep sleep, involving physiological changes and restorative processes

entities.name: N1 STAGE
entities.description: The lightest stage of non-REM sleep, characterized by drifting in and out of consciousness

entities.name: N2 STAGE
entities.description: A stage of non-REM sleep characterized by a decrease in body temperature and heart rate, and the onset of sleep spindles and K-complexes

entities.name: N3 STAGE
entities.description: The deepest stage of non-REM sleep, also known as slow-wave sleep, during which the body undergoes restorative processes

entities.name: CIRCADIAN RHYTHM
entities.description: The body's internal clock that regulates the timing of sleep and wakefulness, influenced by the suprachiasmatic nucleus and melatonin

entities.name: SUPRACHIASMATIC NUCLEUS
entities.description: A region in the brain that acts as the body's master clock, regulating the release of melatonin and influencing the circadian rhythm

entities.name: MELATONIN
entities.description: A hormone that helps promote sleep and is regulated by the circadian rhythm and the suprachiasmatic nucleus

entities.name: ADENOSINE
entities.description: A neurotransmitter that promotes sleep and is part of the sleep-wake cycle regulation

entities.name: SEROTONIN
entities.description: A neurotransmitter that plays a role in the regulation of sleep, among other functions

entities.name: DOPAMINE
entities.description: A neurotransmitter that influences the regulation of sleep and wakefulness

entities.name: INSOMNIA
entities.description: A sleep disorder characterized by difficulty falling or staying asleep, often due to disruptions in neurotransmitter systems

entities.name: NARCOLEPSY
entities.description: A sleep disorder characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness and sudden sleep attacks, often due to disruptions in neurotransmitter systems

entities.name: SLEEP APNEA
entities.description: A sleep disorder characterized by pauses in breathing during sleep, often due to disruptions in neurotransmitter systems

entities.name: OBESITY
entities.description: A condition characterized by excessive body fat, which can be influenced by chronic sleep deprivation

entities.name: DIABETES
entities.description: A metabolic disorder characterized by high blood sugar levels, which can be influenced by chronic sleep deprivation

entities.name: CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASE
entities.description: A group of disorders affecting the heart and blood vessels, which can be influenced by chronic sleep deprivation

entities.name: MENTAL HEALTH DISORDERS
entities.description: A range of conditions affecting mental health, which can be influenced by chronic sleep deprivation

entities.name: CHRONIC SLEEP DEPRIVATION
entities.description: A condition characterized by a persistent lack of adequate sleep, which can have significant negative effects on health and well-being

entities.name: PHYSIOLOGICAL MECHANISMS
entities.description: The bodily processes and functions that are involved in the regulation and maintenance of sleep

entities.name: NEUROLOGICAL MECHANISMS
entities.description: The brain functions and neural processes that are involved in the regulation and maintenance of sleep

entities.name: SLEEP CYCLE
entities.description: The recurring pattern of sleep stages that the body goes through during a period of sleep, typically lasting about 90 minutes

entities.name: SLEEP SPINDLES
entities.description: Brief bursts of brain activity that occur during the N2 stage of non-REM sleep, thought to play a role in memory consolidation

entities.name: K-COMPLEXES
entities.description: Large, high-amplitude brain waves that occur during the N2 stage of non-REM sleep, thought to play a role in sleep stability and memory processing

entities.name: MEMORY CONSOLIDATION
entities.description: The process by which new information is transferred from short-term to long-term memory, often occurring during REM sleep

entities.name: EMOTIONAL PROCESSING
entities.description: The brain's processing of emotional experiences, which is thought to occur during REM sleep

entities.name: IMMUNE FUNCTION
entities.description: The body's ability to defend against diseases and infections, which is influenced by the quality and quantity of sleep

entities.name: METABOLISM
entities.description: The set of life-sustaining chemical reactions in the body, which is influenced by the quality and quantity of sleep

entities.name: COGNITIVE FUNCTION
entities.description: The brain's ability to process information, think, and reason, which is influenced by the quality and quantity of sleep

entities.name: BRIGHT LIGHT
entities.description: Light exposure, especially blue light from electronic devices, that can interfere with the body's production of melatonin and disrupt the sleep-wake cycle

entities.name: NOISE
entities.description: Environmental sounds that can affect the quality of sleep, potentially leading to sleep disturbances

entities.name: TEMPERATURE
entities.description: The ambient temperature of the sleeping environment, which can affect the quality of sleep, with cooler temperatures generally promoting better sleep

entities.name: LIFESTYLE CHOICES
entities.description: Personal habits and behaviors that can impact the quality and quantity of sleep, such as diet, exercise, and stress management

relations: The sleep cycle includes multiple stages of non-REM sleep, which are essential for restorative processes
Sleep spindles occur during the N2 stage of non-REM sleep and are thought to play a role in memory consolidation
K-complexes occur during the N2 stage of non-REM sleep and are thought to play a role in sleep stability and memory processing

Chronic sleep deprivation is linked to an increased risk of diabetes
Chronic sleep deprivation is linked to an increased risk of cardiovascular disease
Chronic sleep deprivation is linked to an increased risk of mental health disorders
Chronic sleep deprivation can have significant negative effects on health and well-being, including increased risks of obesity, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and mental health disorders

REM sleep is thought to play a crucial role in memory consolidation
REM sleep is thought to play a crucial role in emotional processing
Adequate sleep is essential for maintaining a healthy immune function, which is a key component of overall health and well-being
Adequate sleep is essential for maintaining a healthy metabolism, which is a key component of overall health and well-being
Adequate sleep is essential for maintaining optimal cognitive function, which is a key component of overall health and well-being

Personal habits and behaviors, such as diet, exercise, and stress management, can impact the quality and quantity of sleep
